results.title: Gender, early morality, & the self
results.creator_credit: Darrel Schwandt, George A. Colburn, DLGHS and GPN
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “The Worlds of childhood”.
The role of the family in the development of gender roles, moral emotions, prosocial behaviour and self concept are considered. Shows Children’s Day in Japan, boys and girls playing in a day care centre, and the way children’s behaviour outside the family, depends on how they have learned to act towards those in it.

results.title: Gender and relationships
results.creator_credit: Carol Trussell and Coastline Community College
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Psychology: the study of human behavior”.
Close relationships help us achieve fulfilment as human beings. What do we expect from them and how do they change as we change? This program looks at the dynamics of close relationships and the ways in which cultural differences such as gender, the society we live in and our individual histories influence our expectations. The program also explores the relationship between a balance of power within a relationship and the long term success or failure of that relationship.

results.title: Geelong and district : Moving memories 1911 - 1950s
results.creator_credit: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: History comes alive with the rarely seen footage of Geelong and surrounding districts presented on this video. This compilation, selected from newsreels, documentaries, home movies and election propaganda. Featured are the towns of Geelong, Moriac, Queenscliff, Colac, Lorne and Corio. Highlights include: VFL Geelong vs Essendon 1911 ; WWI troops leaving Geelong ; Queenscliff 1923 ; construction of the Great Ocean Road 1920s ; Geelong centenary parade 1938 ; Miss Geelong 1945 ; Barwon floods 1951.

results.title: Geelong's m'name
results.creator_credit: Adrian Boddington, Geelong Harbor Trust Commissioners and Zanthus Films
results.brief_description: ‘The Geelong’ a tug boat in Corio Bay escorts cargo ships and tankers on the four hour journey along the deep but narrow channel into port. The tugs are on call day and night in the busy industrial port. All Geelong’s shipping activities are controlled by the signal station at Point Henry, site of the original settlement of Geelong. Crude oil from Persia, phosphate from Nauru, sulphur from Mexico, are among the cargoes brought to the port, while wool, wheat and meat, products from the rich Western district, are among its exports.

results.title: Gaudi afternoon
results.creator_credit: Susan Seidelman, Andres Gomes, Antenna 3 Television, Lola Films and Via Digital
results.brief_description: Cassandra Reilly (Judy Davis) is a nomadic American translator living in Barcelona, Spain who takes on a missing person job as she is short of funds. She finds herself working for the mysterious and beautiful Frankie Stevens (Marcia Gay Harden). Frankie however does not tell Reilly the full story and Reilly becomes intrigued by different characters that she starts to trail, including Ben (Lili Taylor), a butch American lesbian, April (Juliette Lewis), her bohemian girlfriend and Hamilton, their friend, a bi-sexual magician. Davis plays Cassandra as a clumsy, self-conscious and straight-laced neurotic who is a fish-out-of-water in the ‘exotic’ gay and lesbian scene. A cross-dressing black comedy, “Gaudi afternoon” is an amusing undertaking from director Susan Seidelman (Desperately seeking Susan, She-devil), who spent ten years directing for television before returning to film with this feature. Seidelman never seems to quite make all the elements gel but the impressive cast and beautiful locale go some way to making the film an enjoyable ride. Fans of “Desperately seeking Susan” may be interested to decipher the similarities between the two narratives here.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Susan Seidelman, Andres Gomes, Antenna 3 Television, Lola Films and Via Digital

results.title: Gateway to charm
results.brief_description: the tourist attractions of the north coast of Tasmania. The towns of Wynyard, Burnie, Stanley, Penguin, Ulverston and Devonport are shown, with their beaches, ocean and fresh-water fishing, sporting and camping facilities, and natural scenic attractions. The beauties of the rocky coast are displayed. Aboriginal rock paintings, fossils and the ruins of pioneer settlements can also be seen.
